title: USB C Charger Block 140W, 4 Ports GaN Charger USB C Fast Charging Station Foldable Compact Wall Charger Power Adapter for MacBook Pro, iPhone 16/15, iPad, Galaxy, Steam Deck, Google Pixelbook 140W Midnight Grey
description: 【140W Fast Charging Max】:The USB C Charger Block with 3 USB-C ports and 1 USB-A port, connect a single USB C device to get maximum output 140W, charge your MacBook Pro 16'' to 56% in 30 minutes

This has the power capacity, but unfortunately, this one has some cons that makes this product unusable for my situation. Pros: - It charges 2 MacBooks (one Pro and one Air) with no problems, albeit they don't get much power for charging (definitely not 100W combined) - It has 4 ports, and you can charge 4 devices, if you are not charging 2 computers Cons: - This one is major, but it seems to be the case for most GaN chargers. When you plug in the first device to charge, everything works great. Once you plug in the second device, it disconnects all devices, and reconnects (I know it is due to the circuit to identify the power profile of the new device and how much power to allocate to the device). There are GaN chargers that do not exhibit this behavior, so I am going to have to only buy those for my purpose (powering mini computer and Raspberry Pi) - The other bad behavior which is equally as bad as the first. When you unplug a device from this power brick, it will disconnect power to all devices and then reconnects. Doing this with a computer that has no battery will potentially reboot or kill the device. If you are using this for my intended purpose of powering a mini computer and 2 Pi computers, forget it. It does work well, I just don't trust it to be powered on 24/7. I will keep it for my travel power brick. Hope this helps. Read more","asin":"B0DSFL28MQ","body_html":"
I was looking for a multi port power brick that actually does what it says. I am looking for a multi port power brick powerful enough to power a mini computer (12V/3A), and 2 Raspberry Pi (a 4 and a Zero - total of 2.5A). This has the power capacity, but unfortunately, this one has some cons that makes this product unusable for my situation.

Pros:
- It charges 2 MacBooks (one Pro and one Air) with no problems, albeit they don't get much power for charging (definitely not 100W combined)
- It has 4 ports, and you can charge 4 devices, if you are not charging 2 computers

Cons:
- This one is major, but it seems to be the case for most GaN chargers. When you plug in the first device to charge, everything works great. Once you plug in the second device, it disconnects all devices, and reconnects (I know it is due to the circuit to identify the power profile of the new device and how much power to allocate to the device). There are GaN chargers that do not exhibit this behavior, so I am going to have to only buy those for my purpose (powering mini computer and Raspberry Pi)
- The other bad behavior which is equally as bad as the first. When you unplug a device from this power brick, it will disconnect power to all devices and then reconnects. Doing this with a computer that has no battery will potentially reboot or kill the device. So again, I can't use this for the intended purpose.
- It gets quite warm, to the point of concern of whether I can leave this plugged in 24/7 for my mini computer and Raspberry Pi 4 and Pi Zero)

So the verdict. If you are using this to charge multiple devices, like a MacBook Pro, an iPhone, and AirPods for travel, this is great! If you are using this for my intended purpose of powering a mini computer and 2 Pi computers, forget it.

It does work well, I just don't trust it to be powered on 24/7. I will keep it for my travel power brick.

Hope this helps.
Read more
